Question Set #1:

<a href="https://www.gitbook.com/?utm_source=content&amp;utm_medium=trademark&amp;utm_campaign=-MWyt4j29ReMyImgcaO7" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1uwl36a r-z2wwpe r-1rasi3h r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-1fdo3w0 r-1mnahxq r-ymttw5 r-5njf8e r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-eu3ka r-1aockid" /></a>

Powered By <span class="css-901oao css-16my406 r-b88u0q">GitBook</span>

index

<span key="b72c0511202142f48b2f66468e0072d8"><span offset-key="b72c0511202142f48b2f66468e0072d8:0">This appendix is a non-exhaustive list of new syntactic features and methods that were added to JavaScript in ES6. These features are the most commonly used and most helpful.</span></span>

<span key="67a6e35c4e0146e292d050dbb71db55b"><span offset-key="67a6e35c4e0146e292d050dbb71db55b:0">While this appendix doesn't cover ES6 classes, we go over the basics while learning about components in the book. In addition, this appendix doesn't include descriptions of some larger new features like promises and generators. If you'd like more info on those or on any topic below, we encourage you to reference the </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="0c6f25c49be4474eaa7034522f651478" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-4413_259-4414-237__"><span data-key="f580f032e00949f38e2c72f15d672343"><span data-offset-key="f580f032e00949f38e2c72f15d672343:0">Mozilla Developer Network's website</span></span></span></a><span key="8b7dccdc1f3c4058922ae8a2dab0ac39"><span offset-key="8b7dccdc1f3c4058922ae8a2dab0ac39:0"> (MDN).</span></span>

# 

<span key="8b74f2cc00994c2db1d6e587b5a8aa20"><span offset-key="8b74f2cc00994c2db1d6e587b5a8aa20:0">Prefer </span>`const`<span offset-key="8b74f2cc00994c2db1d6e587b5a8aa20:2"> and </span>`let`<span offset-key="8b74f2cc00994c2db1d6e587b5a8aa20:4"> over </span>`var`</span>

<span key="0942dfc488094eb5afe7d4b9d529a8f0"><span offset-key="0942dfc488094eb5afe7d4b9d529a8f0:0">If you've worked with ES5 JavaScript before, you're likely used to seeing variables declared with </span>`var`<span offset-key="0942dfc488094eb5afe7d4b9d529a8f0:2">:</span></span>

1

<span key="5e1010723704477aa64f3de577a31b44"><span offset-key="5e1010723704477aa64f3de577a31b44:0">ar myVariable = 5;</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7" />

Copied!

<span key="bb85ae822b614fdfb7d2a4ede96ccbd6"><span offset-key="bb85ae822b614fdfb7d2a4ede96ccbd6:0">Both the </span>`const`<span offset-key="bb85ae822b614fdfb7d2a4ede96ccbd6:2"> and </span>`let`<span offset-key="bb85ae822b614fdfb7d2a4ede96ccbd6:4"> statements also declare variables. They were introduced in ES6.</span></span>

<span key="ce590b965c4f470a9480d13ea71e6dbb"><span offset-key="ce590b965c4f470a9480d13ea71e6dbb:0">Use </span>`const`<span offset-key="ce590b965c4f470a9480d13ea71e6dbb:2"> in cases where a variable is never re-assigned. Using </span>`const`<span offset-key="ce590b965c4f470a9480d13ea71e6dbb:4"> makes this clear to whoever is reading your code. It refers to the "constant" state of the variable in the context it is defined within.</span></span>

<span key="d9f0db743469404eb3c8fc88b017423f"><span offset-key="d9f0db743469404eb3c8fc88b017423f:0">If the variable will be re-assigned, use </span>`let`<span offset-key="d9f0db743469404eb3c8fc88b017423f:2">.</span></span>

<span key="c4a3455b3dde42efb7b89a91072b575d"><span offset-key="c4a3455b3dde42efb7b89a91072b575d:0">We encourage the use of </span>`const`<span offset-key="c4a3455b3dde42efb7b89a91072b575d:2"> and </span>`let`<span offset-key="c4a3455b3dde42efb7b89a91072b575d:4"> instead of </span>`var`<span offset-key="c4a3455b3dde42efb7b89a91072b575d:6">. In addition to the restriction introduced by </span>`const`<span offset-key="c4a3455b3dde42efb7b89a91072b575d:8">, both </span>`const`<span offset-key="c4a3455b3dde42efb7b89a91072b575d:10"> and </span>`let`<span offset-key="c4a3455b3dde42efb7b89a91072b575d:12"> are </span>*block scoped*<span offset-key="c4a3455b3dde42efb7b89a91072b575d:14"> as opposed to </span>*function scoped*<span offset-key="c4a3455b3dde42efb7b89a91072b575d:16">. This scoping can help avoid unexpected bugs.</span></span>

# 

<span key="12c0b56ffacd48a19f362b8e3678081a"><span offset-key="12c0b56ffacd48a19f362b8e3678081a:0">Arrow functions</span></span>

<span key="bd75283ad5de4ea18b0ae6bfe2a1b823"><span offset-key="bd75283ad5de4ea18b0ae6bfe2a1b823:0">There are three ways to write arrow function bodies. For the examples below, let's say we have an array of city objects:</span></span>

1

<span key="f881a300d20249c7bf7a3b560c7d5fe2"><span offset-key="f881a300d20249c7bf7a3b560c7d5fe2:0">onst cities = \[</span></span>

2

<span key="727f8f0ea54c4316922ef27bc5de70c7"><span offset-key="727f8f0ea54c4316922ef27bc5de70c7:0"> { name: 'Cairo', pop: 7764700 },</span></span>

3

<span key="1ce32821a514434193ca8957b6acd2eb"><span offset-key="1ce32821a514434193ca8957b6acd2eb:0"> { name: 'Lagos', pop: 8029200 },</span></span>

4

<span key="9d224a68f31d46d9a2edc33ac618dc01"><span offset-key="9d224a68f31d46d9a2edc33ac618dc01:0">\];</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0c5d89afb2fe4c2bb9acd3d82d7a8228"><span offset-key="0c5d89afb2fe4c2bb9acd3d82d7a8228:0">If we write an arrow function that spans multiple lines, we must use braces to delimit the function body like this:</span></span>

1

<span key="d5da79b816644468bdeb888e8e64c92f"><span offset-key="d5da79b816644468bdeb888e8e64c92f:0">const formattedPopulations = cities.map((city) => {</span></span>

2

<span key="35b2e09fe08440dfb792e3c730a887a5"><span offset-key="35b2e09fe08440dfb792e3c730a887a5:0"> const popMM = (city.pop / 1000000).toFixed(2);</span></span>

3

<span key="e3746c8488bc45ed8cb53b729aec97b2"><span offset-key="e3746c8488bc45ed8cb53b729aec97b2:0"> return popMM + ' million';</span></span>

4

<span key="da42e84ffcf640bd9b88b91edb79c795"><span offset-key="da42e84ffcf640bd9b88b91edb79c795:0">});</span></span>

5

<span key="d1082b32890b4c3e8530daf97d7ac0ad"><span offset-key="d1082b32890b4c3e8530daf97d7ac0ad:0">console.log(formattedPopulations);</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="8a67832fb3204177a937c2ecb17c97e6"><span offset-key="8a67832fb3204177a937c2ecb17c97e6:0">Note that we must also explicitly specify a </span>`return`<span offset-key="8a67832fb3204177a937c2ecb17c97e6:2"> for the function.</span></span>

<span key="dd7e8d5e1d824e12ae511e4911c8a1d8"><span offset-key="dd7e8d5e1d824e12ae511e4911c8a1d8:0">However, if we write a function body that is only a single line (or single expression) we can use parentheses to delimit it:</span></span>

1

<span key="3c14e514295e404a83f4e2326ddc1055"><span offset-key="3c14e514295e404a83f4e2326ddc1055:0">const formattedPopulations2 = cities.map((city) => (</span></span>

2

<span key="d4cba286fd2347a19f2b173a84be7606"><span offset-key="d4cba286fd2347a19f2b173a84be7606:0"> (city.pop / 1000000).toFixed(2) + ' million'</span></span>

3

<span key="5580de85cb8c498b8e4424156a4f6150"><span offset-key="5580de85cb8c498b8e4424156a4f6150:0">));</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="51fd05306e5f4999a2af17aa58f996a1"><span offset-key="51fd05306e5f4999a2af17aa58f996a1:0">Notably, we don't use </span>`return`<span offset-key="51fd05306e5f4999a2af17aa58f996a1:2"> as it's implied.</span></span>

<span key="19f3d55be1664cf791c76de8fbbabadb"><span offset-key="19f3d55be1664cf791c76de8fbbabadb:0">Furthermore, if your function body is terse you can write it like so:</span></span>

1

<span key="acded4fd3410413dac1b5025e8a973eb"><span offset-key="acded4fd3410413dac1b5025e8a973eb:0">const pops = cities.map(city => city.pop);</span></span>

2

<span key="395ee6643efb4cb9925ff8b1ecabde6a"><span offset-key="395ee6643efb4cb9925ff8b1ecabde6a:0">console.log(pops);</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="f3c132d77d2f4e30bcc4f7a2903d29fc"><span offset-key="f3c132d77d2f4e30bcc4f7a2903d29fc:0">The terseness of arrow functions is one of two reasons that we use them. Compare the one-liner above to this:</span></span>

1

<span key="f7d35eb199ef46b3900bc1aa706ea66e"><span offset-key="f7d35eb199ef46b3900bc1aa706ea66e:0">const popsNoArrow = cities.map(function(city) { return city.pop });</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b6be68e4619e4b89adf4850078c44749"><span offset-key="b6be68e4619e4b89adf4850078c44749:0">Of greater benefit, though, is how arrow functions bind the </span>`this`<span offset-key="b6be68e4619e4b89adf4850078c44749:2"> object.</span></span>

<span key="ffbb054c6696452996576934840be113"><span offset-key="ffbb054c6696452996576934840be113:0">The traditional JavaScript function declaration syntax (</span>`function () {}`<span offset-key="ffbb054c6696452996576934840be113:2">) will bind </span>`this`<span offset-key="ffbb054c6696452996576934840be113:4"> in anonymous functions to the global object. To illustrate the confusion this causes, consider the following example:</span></span>

1

<span key="58e1cbe39128421dae0ff93fe579e7d4"><span offset-key="58e1cbe39128421dae0ff93fe579e7d4:0">unction printSong() {</span></span>

2

<span key="e910813deb6c48f4bc3cd828094e3af3"><span offset-key="e910813deb6c48f4bc3cd828094e3af3:0"> console.log("Oops - The Global Object");</span></span>

3

<span key="c1670421504142dca02f041d390aa987"><span offset-key="c1670421504142dca02f041d390aa987:0">}</span></span>

4

<span key="d3781331e689426ba13b61bdfae0e79b"><span offset-key="d3781331e689426ba13b61bdfae0e79b:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

5

<span key="ee33611b7f4d4aaa80131c8b75c7839f"><span offset-key="ee33611b7f4d4aaa80131c8b75c7839f:0">const jukebox = {</span></span>

6

<span key="9052e4a6f1794052930e6a91aea8cb78"><span offset-key="9052e4a6f1794052930e6a91aea8cb78:0"> songs: \[</span></span>

7

<span key="2b107980db1a4d05858b465808bdfdb7"><span offset-key="2b107980db1a4d05858b465808bdfdb7:0"> {</span></span>

8

<span key="5bc55f8cd0c44506abac04d624f31c59"><span offset-key="5bc55f8cd0c44506abac04d624f31c59:0"> title: "Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'",</span></span>

9

<span key="8962e39f9d8448549fb617c09992b1fa"><span offset-key="8962e39f9d8448549fb617c09992b1fa:0"> artist: "Michael Jackson",</span></span>

10

<span key="76d89bb7f502406bb42ab0ddf022dae3"><span offset-key="76d89bb7f502406bb42ab0ddf022dae3:0"> },</span></span>

11

<span key="b19a247e0f6c40138f35150520870400"><span offset-key="b19a247e0f6c40138f35150520870400:0"> {</span></span>

12

<span key="dac1b47502ab4c69b0528c642e9c4594"><span offset-key="dac1b47502ab4c69b0528c642e9c4594:0"> title: "Superstar",</span></span>

13

<span key="15a1023d874d4c21af1ae87fc70193cf"><span offset-key="15a1023d874d4c21af1ae87fc70193cf:0"> artist: "Madonna",</span></span>

14

<span key="3b33b359e58346829a898917b0fa6ae0"><span offset-key="3b33b359e58346829a898917b0fa6ae0:0"> },</span></span>

15

<span key="cae4d2e498004e75a049a77793d70f74"><span offset-key="cae4d2e498004e75a049a77793d70f74:0"> \],</span></span>

16

<span key="f4ddd2d5ec5742f492ed7be08cd0e7e6"><span offset-key="f4ddd2d5ec5742f492ed7be08cd0e7e6:0"> printSong: function (song) {</span></span>

17

<span key="efc0b04e4e254c54a0d64984115d7813"><span offset-key="efc0b04e4e254c54a0d64984115d7813:0"> console.log(song.title + " - " + song.artist);</span></span>

18

<span key="26adebd5ec424f228df1fd316050ec27"><span offset-key="26adebd5ec424f228df1fd316050ec27:0"> },</span></span>

19

Copied!

<span key="b1a6c218c6674b97844b1104161f98f1"><span offset-key="b1a6c218c6674b97844b1104161f98f1:0">The method </span>`printSongs()`<span offset-key="b1a6c218c6674b97844b1104161f98f1:2"> iterates over </span>`this.songs`<span offset-key="b1a6c218c6674b97844b1104161f98f1:4"> with </span>`forEach()`<span offset-key="b1a6c218c6674b97844b1104161f98f1:6">. In this context, </span>`this`<span offset-key="b1a6c218c6674b97844b1104161f98f1:8"> is bound to the object (</span>`jukebox`<span offset-key="b1a6c218c6674b97844b1104161f98f1:10">) as expected. However, the anonymous function passed to </span>`forEach()`<span offset-key="b1a6c218c6674b97844b1104161f98f1:12"> binds its internal </span>`this`<span offset-key="b1a6c218c6674b97844b1104161f98f1:14"> to the global object. As such, </span>`this.printSong(song)`<span offset-key="b1a6c218c6674b97844b1104161f98f1:16"> calls the function declared at the top of the example, </span>*not*<span offset-key="b1a6c218c6674b97844b1104161f98f1:18"> the method on </span>`jukebox`<span offset-key="b1a6c218c6674b97844b1104161f98f1:20">.</span></span>

<span key="7e1025fc54a247c4a92f40f81be8958d"><span offset-key="7e1025fc54a247c4a92f40f81be8958d:0">JavaScript developers have traditionally used workarounds for this behavior, but arrow functions solve the problem by </span>**capturing the** **`this`** **value of the enclosing context**<span offset-key="7e1025fc54a247c4a92f40f81be8958d:4">. Using an arrow function for </span>`printSongs()`<span offset-key="7e1025fc54a247c4a92f40f81be8958d:6"> has the expected result:</span></span>

1

<span key="ae91a7475291435598c58d2e4b7cc4cb"><span offset-key="ae91a7475291435598c58d2e4b7cc4cb:0"> printSongs: function () {</span></span>

2

<span key="1a38a19219a84db88a6b6600388a9f13"><span offset-key="1a38a19219a84db88a6b6600388a9f13:0"> this.songs.forEach((song) => {</span></span>

3

<span key="4b830a20fe1e47dc8ce7e9a3a3237a33"><span offset-key="4b830a20fe1e47dc8ce7e9a3a3237a33:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

4

<span key="ed93dcb9d58b4989b738ba9112ea5bf6"><span offset-key="ed93dcb9d58b4989b738ba9112ea5bf6:0"> this.printSong(song);</span></span>

5

<span key="5b4ac8e9f2fc405593fad529be816581"><span offset-key="5b4ac8e9f2fc405593fad529be816581:0"> });</span></span>

6

<span key="e57a475ede944998a0edb2035915a792"><span offset-key="e57a475ede944998a0edb2035915a792:0"> },</span></span>

<span key="c83da280a1674dfb8193c3b11f43b0ce"><span offset-key="c83da280a1674dfb8193c3b11f43b0ce:0">}</span></span>

<span key="d33cd22238cd4c1bb3d22a22a3d954ea"><span offset-key="d33cd22238cd4c1bb3d22a22a3d954ea:0">For this reason, throughout the book we use arrow functions for all anonymous functions.</span></span>

# 

<span key="b2e2fca8ed7b44679799d68d65c2335a"><span offset-key="b2e2fca8ed7b44679799d68d65c2335a:0">Modules</span></span>

<span key="33078aafc8294a7e9749eeb7df4b818c"><span offset-key="33078aafc8294a7e9749eeb7df4b818c:0">ES6 formally supports modules using the </span>`import`<span offset-key="33078aafc8294a7e9749eeb7df4b818c:2">/</span>`export`<span offset-key="33078aafc8294a7e9749eeb7df4b818c:4"> syntax.</span></span>

<span key="13ead8bba4af4709ac657e6328573a06">**Named exports**</span>

<span key="5bf9437768544f6ba1fc4ce7f5cb2ea8"><span offset-key="5bf9437768544f6ba1fc4ce7f5cb2ea8:0">Inside any file, you can use </span>`export`<span offset-key="5bf9437768544f6ba1fc4ce7f5cb2ea8:2"> to specify a variable the module should expose. Here's an example of a file that exports two functions:</span></span>

1

<span key="06413ae8f6e74e1384519869583bed26"><span offset-key="06413ae8f6e74e1384519869583bed26:0">export const sayHi = () => (console.log('Hi!'));</span></span>

2

<span key="e3ddb13166e14a4ba647f41fb8e71e13"><span offset-key="e3ddb13166e14a4ba647f41fb8e71e13:0">export const sayBye = () => (console.log('Bye!'));</span></span>

3

<span key="39aaa352794b4c5d9634bf6f4bbca71c"><span offset-key="39aaa352794b4c5d9634bf6f4bbca71c:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

4

<span key="7f68de8dca924f8f8bdce89d95b68926"><span offset-key="7f68de8dca924f8f8bdce89d95b68926:0">const saySomething = () => (console.log('Something!'));</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a07ca171e4114e099d5e28b20ba6e865"><span offset-key="a07ca171e4114e099d5e28b20ba6e865:0">Now, anywhere we wanted to use these functions we could use </span>`import`<span offset-key="a07ca171e4114e099d5e28b20ba6e865:2">. We need to specify which functions we want to import. A common way of doing this is using ES6's destructuring assignment syntax to list them out like this:</span></span>

1

<span key="6bf42d436082447e9d17c22be3f89c8d"><span offset-key="6bf42d436082447e9d17c22be3f89c8d:0">import { sayHi, sayBye } from './greetings';</span></span>

2

<span key="503f342e1c9c4788bb06089d36f63233"><span offset-key="503f342e1c9c4788bb06089d36f63233:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

3

<span key="70540e2283f043b4acf57d61e14b7864"><span offset-key="70540e2283f043b4acf57d61e14b7864:0">sayHi(); </span></span>

4

<span key="94f232973e4a448da53e50778a889c47"><span offset-key="94f232973e4a448da53e50778a889c47:0">sayBye();</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a8cac3b4a2f1499c83ba56a1b6d55cbd"><span offset-key="a8cac3b4a2f1499c83ba56a1b6d55cbd:0">Importantly, the function that was </span>*not*<span offset-key="a8cac3b4a2f1499c83ba56a1b6d55cbd:2"> exported (</span>`saySomething`<span offset-key="a8cac3b4a2f1499c83ba56a1b6d55cbd:4">) is unavailable outside of the module.</span></span>

<span key="44d4a3e450124b50bf398880d26a0694"><span offset-key="44d4a3e450124b50bf398880d26a0694:0">Also note that we supply a </span>**relative path**<span offset-key="44d4a3e450124b50bf398880d26a0694:2"> to </span>`from`<span offset-key="44d4a3e450124b50bf398880d26a0694:4">, indicating that the ES6 module is a local file as opposed to an npm package.</span></span>

<span key="b14a5a08e5a949879235f1affc04e1f8"><span offset-key="b14a5a08e5a949879235f1affc04e1f8:0">Instead of inserting an </span>`export`<span offset-key="b14a5a08e5a949879235f1affc04e1f8:2"> before each variable you'd like to export, you can use this syntax to list off all the exposed variables in one area:</span></span>

1

<span key="ff786a1210c34f50945895a1cc84c867"><span offset-key="ff786a1210c34f50945895a1cc84c867:0">const sayHi = () => (console.log('Hi!'));</span></span>

2

<span key="27834577cc9b419b9e652ed3f34b881c"><span offset-key="27834577cc9b419b9e652ed3f34b881c:0">const sayBye = () => (console.log('Bye!'));</span></span>

3

<span key="68d9a7d84bac4889a70c723d405e2893"><span offset-key="68d9a7d84bac4889a70c723d405e2893:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

4

<span key="a74c32a37c9742a081440e2919b9bcdb"><span offset-key="a74c32a37c9742a081440e2919b9bcdb:0">const saySomething = () => (console.log('Something!'));</span></span>

5

<span key="ac6b4be0657a4195bdbc87fb961b58cb"><span offset-key="ac6b4be0657a4195bdbc87fb961b58cb:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

<span key="92fa130923e446379d471a60d009d500"><span offset-key="92fa130923e446379d471a60d009d500:0">export { sayHi, sayBye };</span></span>

Copied!

<span key="92906a061c5b4036aa7c905e77c6ea88"><span offset-key="92906a061c5b4036aa7c905e77c6ea88:0">We can also specify that we'd like to import all of a module's functionality underneath a given namespace with the </span>`import * as <Namespace>`<span offset-key="92906a061c5b4036aa7c905e77c6ea88:2"> syntax:</span></span>

<span key="408e5b0ccbdf45249628b51258ff0bcb"><span offset-key="408e5b0ccbdf45249628b51258ff0bcb:0">import \* as Greetings from './greetings';</span></span>

<span key="9cac8d4078a64b77a8589891fe5ab461">**Default export**</span>

<span key="decd5478d4aa4d0497fba071063d3245"><span offset-key="decd5478d4aa4d0497fba071063d3245:0">The other type of export is a default export. A module can only contain one default export:</span></span>

1

<span key="1f9bc29ae15a4296a9f34039e889e2b2"><span offset-key="1f9bc29ae15a4296a9f34039e889e2b2:0">const sayHi = () => (console.log('Hi!'));</span></span>

<span key="87f0cbf4add44f6cb7764e7eaedbef84"><span offset-key="87f0cbf4add44f6cb7764e7eaedbef84:0">const sayBye = () => (console.log('Bye!'));</span></span>

<span key="46147d6c66f340edb98b5fe531ab2bff"><span offset-key="46147d6c66f340edb98b5fe531ab2bff:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

Copied!

<span key="df0e3804e83d421f9fdb1d7ca8276999"><span offset-key="df0e3804e83d421f9fdb1d7ca8276999:0">If you want to play around with the module syntax, check out the folder </span>`code/webpack/es6-modules`<span offset-key="df0e3804e83d421f9fdb1d7ca8276999:2">.</span></span>

<span key="36b60797cfa64e0ca84348f5b07c1d2d"><span offset-key="36b60797cfa64e0ca84348f5b07c1d2d:0">For more reading on ES6 modules, see this article from Mozilla: "</span></span><a href="https://hacks.mozilla.org/2015/08/es6-in-depth-modules/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="745a8529e5434b8d860e112375bb726d" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-4413_259-4414-237__"><span data-key="7265798c4f8e4dec95c59ec085fbe35a"><span data-offset-key="7265798c4f8e4dec95c59ec085fbe35a:0">ES6 in Depth: Modules</span></span></span></a><span key="d32a3e09a2b344ef802ac38180f8329b"><span offset-key="d32a3e09a2b344ef802ac38180f8329b:0">".</span></span>

# 

<span key="7b87d549a2644d82b43e0539fe434b4d">`Object.assign()`</span>

<span key="ba1315e131ae4f6d824bcca8c9bce25d"><span offset-key="ba1315e131ae4f6d824bcca8c9bce25d:0">We use </span>`Object.assign()`<span offset-key="ba1315e131ae4f6d824bcca8c9bce25d:2"> often throughout the book. We use it in areas where we want to create a modified version of an existing object.</span></span>

<span key="daf550c2627e4f8d9c10b9375634a731">`Object.assign()`<span offset-key="daf550c2627e4f8d9c10b9375634a731:1"> accepts any number of objects as arguments. When the function receives two arguments, it </span>*copies*<span offset-key="daf550c2627e4f8d9c10b9375634a731:3"> the properties of the second object onto the first, like so:</span></span>

1

<span key="a4f096d9452c4ab09e55685cbafa1209"><span offset-key="a4f096d9452c4ab09e55685cbafa1209:0">onst coffee = { };</span></span>

2

<span key="086bc5f95d724264867c8eb97fae6863"><span offset-key="086bc5f95d724264867c8eb97fae6863:0">const noCream = { cream: false };</span></span>

3

<span key="876a780e8db347a8901481fc6b1f5807"><span offset-key="876a780e8db347a8901481fc6b1f5807:0">const noMilk = { milk: false };</span></span>

4

<span key="3bd0007773624b3f8fac0043f87926ef"><span offset-key="3bd0007773624b3f8fac0043f87926ef:0">Object.assign(coffee, noCream);</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="fb26e3956c194481b4105625369fa5cc"><span offset-key="fb26e3956c194481b4105625369fa5cc:0">It is idiomatic to pass in three arguments to </span>`Object.assign()`<span offset-key="fb26e3956c194481b4105625369fa5cc:2">. The first argument is a new JavaScript object, the one that </span>`Object.assign()`<span offset-key="fb26e3956c194481b4105625369fa5cc:4"> will ultimately return. The second is the object whose properties we'd like to build off of. The last is the changes we'd like to apply:</span></span>

1

<span key="6c29871c31304be9a7ce53be7d2387db"><span offset-key="6c29871c31304be9a7ce53be7d2387db:0">const coffeeWithMilk = Object.assign({}, coffee, { milk: true });</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="7af4cfd555db4986bcbb3d9950d622e7">`Object.assign()`<span offset-key="7af4cfd555db4986bcbb3d9950d622e7:1"> is a handy method for working with "immutable" JavaScript objects.</span></span>

# 

<span key="2fd2ed145af640b7bf359d401393c099"><span offset-key="2fd2ed145af640b7bf359d401393c099:0">Template literals</span></span>

<span key="0fd07289be0e452bbe4a943d9201d9de"><span offset-key="0fd07289be0e452bbe4a943d9201d9de:0">In ES5 JavaScript, you'd interpolate variables into strings like this:</span></span>

1

<span key="58db4c877dbf43c29ce367f8795d8a8f"><span offset-key="58db4c877dbf43c29ce367f8795d8a8f:0">var greeting = 'Hello, ' + user + '! It is ' + degF + ' degrees outside.';</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="7c56ba3350a04b13bcec2d85d1ceefb5"><span offset-key="7c56ba3350a04b13bcec2d85d1ceefb5:0">With ES6 template literals, we can create the same string like this:</span></span>

1

<span key="860366e0b99143e5bd4502d3f17a0d87"><span offset-key="860366e0b99143e5bd4502d3f17a0d87:0">const greeting = \`Hello, ${user}! It is ${degF} degrees outside.\`;</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

# 

<span key="ebbccbefd9b0451eb77afe9c4c1b6cf4"><span offset-key="ebbccbefd9b0451eb77afe9c4c1b6cf4:0">The spread operator (</span>`...`<span offset-key="ebbccbefd9b0451eb77afe9c4c1b6cf4:2">)</span></span>

<span key="3bfbf1e724604c919d2fcd390d765741"><span offset-key="3bfbf1e724604c919d2fcd390d765741:0">In arrays, the ellipsis </span>`...`<span offset-key="3bfbf1e724604c919d2fcd390d765741:2"> operator will </span>*expand*<span offset-key="3bfbf1e724604c919d2fcd390d765741:4"> the array that follows into the parent array. The spread operator enables us to succinctly construct new arrays as a composite of existing arrays.</span></span>

<span key="7f87c0c1e7b847c8bcd90c74580b7784"><span offset-key="7f87c0c1e7b847c8bcd90c74580b7784:0">Here is an example:</span></span>

1

<span key="990db6d93d114809824320e4f89b7163"><span offset-key="990db6d93d114809824320e4f89b7163:0">onst a = \[ 1, 2, 3 \];</span></span>

2

<span key="3955c76e8836492da4c44f82e5fd956b"><span offset-key="3955c76e8836492da4c44f82e5fd956b:0">const b = \[ 4, 5, 6 \];</span></span>

3

<span key="bfcdb1b2f35741d18455d91f464e7521"><span offset-key="bfcdb1b2f35741d18455d91f464e7521:0">const c = \[ ...a, ...b, 7, 8, 9 \];</span></span>

4

<span key="7a97c618e0e146e3a2bc81ec0b0061d1"><span offset-key="7a97c618e0e146e3a2bc81ec0b0061d1:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

5

<span key="4113c55822ec4fa39026e7a579c1ce18"><span offset-key="4113c55822ec4fa39026e7a579c1ce18:0">console.log(c);</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="db4033246a09410484618f79d5c2ff01"><span offset-key="db4033246a09410484618f79d5c2ff01:0">Notice how this is different than if we wrote:</span></span>

1

<span key="bb85ac6b9d2541eeaa1c7ca230c3a2ae"><span offset-key="bb85ac6b9d2541eeaa1c7ca230c3a2ae:0">const d = \[ a, b, 7, 8, 9 \];</span></span>

2

<span key="1df34235a8b343789fd5608805ef9467"><span offset-key="1df34235a8b343789fd5608805ef9467:0">console.log(d);</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

# 

<span key="98b3a378c3994517b6e8496606c1f759"><span offset-key="98b3a378c3994517b6e8496606c1f759:0">Enhanced object literals</span></span>

<span key="eafb90e0edc94d9994047d3871374eb0"><span offset-key="eafb90e0edc94d9994047d3871374eb0:0">In ES5, all objects were required to have explicit key and value declarations:</span></span>

1

<span key="2c802d9341184d14b9e731e4015bf493"><span offset-key="2c802d9341184d14b9e731e4015bf493:0">const explicit = {</span></span>

2

<span key="6735d98262a74339986364997876ed8a"><span offset-key="6735d98262a74339986364997876ed8a:0"> getState: getState,</span></span>

3

<span key="24346f5943cd44799fbfcb5941b07e0e"><span offset-key="24346f5943cd44799fbfcb5941b07e0e:0"> dispatch: dispatch,</span></span>

4

<span key="85d00bbecfac4903bd88cb2b9933a5ea"><span offset-key="85d00bbecfac4903bd88cb2b9933a5ea:0">};</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e63fc5571ddc421497fb83d3ce17dc3e"><span offset-key="e63fc5571ddc421497fb83d3ce17dc3e:0">In ES6, you can use this terser syntax whenever the property name and variable name are the same:</span></span>

1

<span key="1030c2c10eb445e0b33fbc6e7511f536"><span offset-key="1030c2c10eb445e0b33fbc6e7511f536:0">const implicit = {</span></span>

2

<span key="6e921fbd28184b44823b68bfac437c55"><span offset-key="6e921fbd28184b44823b68bfac437c55:0"> getState,</span></span>

3

<span key="123232949f7f41269b1230bf0c3ed9ba"><span offset-key="123232949f7f41269b1230bf0c3ed9ba:0"> dispatch,</span></span>

4

<span key="9bef721725b24d8aa561f6bf5c82e841"><span offset-key="9bef721725b24d8aa561f6bf5c82e841:0">};</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ca4c5ae32c89447ba202b643fc0ba4ca"><span offset-key="ca4c5ae32c89447ba202b643fc0ba4ca:0">Lots of open source libraries use this syntax, so it's good to be familiar with it. But whether you use it in your own code is a matter of stylistic preference.</span></span>

# 

<span key="6aeeeecac8d944ed96cb3ffb0663c9b4"><span offset-key="6aeeeecac8d944ed96cb3ffb0663c9b4:0">Default arguments</span></span>

<span key="8a3e8cf83578474087199d98cab231b1"><span offset-key="8a3e8cf83578474087199d98cab231b1:0">With ES6, you can specify a default value for an argument in the case that it is </span>`undefined`<span offset-key="8a3e8cf83578474087199d98cab231b1:2"> when the function is called.</span></span>

<span key="1e5b1ed7ba2b4ba99f5e63258535552c"><span offset-key="1e5b1ed7ba2b4ba99f5e63258535552c:0">This:</span></span>

1

<span key="830387d30f414a2395acd8323481b905"><span offset-key="830387d30f414a2395acd8323481b905:0">unction divide(a, b) {</span></span>

2

<span key="d2e50446b10c4d9aa6a252403d6dc25d"><span offset-key="d2e50446b10c4d9aa6a252403d6dc25d:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

3

<span key="38e62a38085043ac8d2df788df344776"><span offset-key="38e62a38085043ac8d2df788df344776:0"> const divisor = typeof b === 'undefined' ? 1 : b;</span></span>

4

<span key="94935b56fda94778a3b7f5541c75e393"><span offset-key="94935b56fda94778a3b7f5541c75e393:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

5

<span key="4d08893c7395440cb92944673319df38"><span offset-key="4d08893c7395440cb92944673319df38:0"> return a / divisor;</span></span>

6

<span key="c596f2f69b37490280ec7330215d603b"><span offset-key="c596f2f69b37490280ec7330215d603b:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="27caa919dd184f9280a48594ebf5712b"><span offset-key="27caa919dd184f9280a48594ebf5712b:0">Can be written as this:</span></span>

1

<span key="e7298c2a4ac44f6da61b5076c116531d"><span offset-key="e7298c2a4ac44f6da61b5076c116531d:0">function divide(a, b = 1) {</span></span>

2

<span key="3a6d3283c7a6440c8c845acc17b3d961"><span offset-key="3a6d3283c7a6440c8c845acc17b3d961:0"> return a / b;</span></span>

3

<span key="eae3eda8070d4e35803932f0725680a5"><span offset-key="eae3eda8070d4e35803932f0725680a5:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="227d086fb6dd4423b561892503ff4da0"><span offset-key="227d086fb6dd4423b561892503ff4da0:0">In both cases, using the function looks like this:</span></span>

1

<span key="dd07ea3c1fd24a28bcfad8c8c24991ec"><span offset-key="dd07ea3c1fd24a28bcfad8c8c24991ec:0">divide(14, 2);</span></span>

2

<span key="8abe55d83e72488484888e2e11b3f216"><span offset-key="8abe55d83e72488484888e2e11b3f216:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

3

<span key="84478eca193947f5ac649166a9b8c85a"><span offset-key="84478eca193947f5ac649166a9b8c85a:0">divide(14, undefined);</span></span>

4

<span key="c8a8746142014f0eab8c6f6dcf277728"><span offset-key="c8a8746142014f0eab8c6f6dcf277728:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

5

<span key="586c341006bf49b58a89e0f0f03e2627"><span offset-key="586c341006bf49b58a89e0f0f03e2627:0">divide(14);</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0c2c462bef10472986f361904f112ad5"><span offset-key="0c2c462bef10472986f361904f112ad5:0">Whenever the argument </span>`b`<span offset-key="0c2c462bef10472986f361904f112ad5:2"> in the example above is </span>`undefined`<span offset-key="0c2c462bef10472986f361904f112ad5:4">, the default argument is used. Note that </span>`null`<span offset-key="0c2c462bef10472986f361904f112ad5:6"> will not use the default argument:</span></span>

1

<span key="4542e3cd6fb34d76ae2a4c06b52d60f2"><span offset-key="4542e3cd6fb34d76ae2a4c06b52d60f2:0">divide(14, null);</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

# 

<span key="2a51a23135bd4706bbf9108b78c708b7"><span offset-key="2a51a23135bd4706bbf9108b78c708b7:0">Destructuring assignments</span></span>

## 

<span key="20a3f4551b5c46eda69510c6d6fbd74b"><span offset-key="20a3f4551b5c46eda69510c6d6fbd74b:0">For arrays</span></span>

<span key="daa51f2227cc4098a69849bd9b2db5b5"><span offset-key="daa51f2227cc4098a69849bd9b2db5b5:0">In ES5, extracting and assigning multiple elements from an array looked like this:</span></span>

1

<span key="d1f4340640e34ec983145409dfe7c56a"><span offset-key="d1f4340640e34ec983145409dfe7c56a:0">ar fruits = \[ 'apples', 'bananas', 'oranges' \];</span></span>

2

<span key="09f9bf40bc394516b2206be17a7b89a1"><span offset-key="09f9bf40bc394516b2206be17a7b89a1:0">var fruit1 = fruits\[0\];</span></span>

3

<span key="84a2d572590c4bbf824b81e69eb06c82"><span offset-key="84a2d572590c4bbf824b81e69eb06c82:0">var fruit2 = fruits\[1\];</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="f25076fa961a4633832f332694caf361"><span offset-key="f25076fa961a4633832f332694caf361:0">In ES6, we can use the destructuring syntax to accomplish the same task like this:</span></span>

1

<span key="d4c0f0f94530424aae3a34a6a96585a0"><span offset-key="d4c0f0f94530424aae3a34a6a96585a0:0">const \[ veg1, veg2 \] = \[ 'asparagus', 'broccoli', 'onion' \];</span></span>

2

<span key="4f6db768b21143eebdff7e9eca1f3683"><span offset-key="4f6db768b21143eebdff7e9eca1f3683:0">console.log(veg1); </span></span>

3

<span key="c40d5846d03a4b1196e1f981ddd67303"><span offset-key="c40d5846d03a4b1196e1f981ddd67303:0">console.log(veg2);</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a9abd04372ff4c63956c19302ba293cc"><span offset-key="a9abd04372ff4c63956c19302ba293cc:0">The variables in the array on the left are "matched" and assigned to the corresponding elements in the array on the right. Note that </span>`'onion'`<span offset-key="a9abd04372ff4c63956c19302ba293cc:2"> is ignored and has no variable bound to it.</span></span>

## 

<span key="41f80bbc6049498cb5e32161d6963a9d"><span offset-key="41f80bbc6049498cb5e32161d6963a9d:0">For objects</span></span>

<span key="3945987c90d24376ad0f69f9f90d8b3e"><span offset-key="3945987c90d24376ad0f69f9f90d8b3e:0">We can do something similar for extracting object properties into variables:</span></span>

1

<span key="fe5ef005a63c4162a35a7741b22f51ad"><span offset-key="fe5ef005a63c4162a35a7741b22f51ad:0">const smoothie = {</span></span>

2

<span key="aa62f2003013430cbf31d9d2c93eecc6"><span offset-key="aa62f2003013430cbf31d9d2c93eecc6:0"> fats: \[ 'avocado', 'peanut butter', 'greek yogurt' \],</span></span>

3

<span key="fd16d1cb44544da5b019ab036b08d492"><span offset-key="fd16d1cb44544da5b019ab036b08d492:0"> liquids: \[ 'almond milk' \],</span></span>

4

<span key="b82a03383c664a05b59df9dd194aa899"><span offset-key="b82a03383c664a05b59df9dd194aa899:0"> greens: \[ 'spinach' \],</span></span>

5

<span key="000cb96c932d45b0b06445af8bb50731"><span offset-key="000cb96c932d45b0b06445af8bb50731:0"> fruits: \[ 'blueberry', 'banana' \],</span></span>

6

<span key="b90099d2c61a4663877a531ec298b93e"><span offset-key="b90099d2c61a4663877a531ec298b93e:0">};</span></span>

7

<span key="dbe131f4d49042ebbafa293cff0e188d"><span offset-key="dbe131f4d49042ebbafa293cff0e188d:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

8

<span key="0a0f50788a914d2b837c6ff0e6fcdd96"><span offset-key="0a0f50788a914d2b837c6ff0e6fcdd96:0">const { liquids, fruits } = smoothie;</span></span>

9

<span key="881201f53ec241fe99b3f9d5c28f04e5"><span offset-key="881201f53ec241fe99b3f9d5c28f04e5:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

10

<span key="f088e752a2ed4de2b58882a613b51b5f"><span offset-key="f088e752a2ed4de2b58882a613b51b5f:0">console.log(liquids); </span></span>

11

<span key="b7709c9fe2864cf4b6f03853d3894d75"><span offset-key="b7709c9fe2864cf4b6f03853d3894d75:0">console.log(fruits);</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="ceb3eaceff2c47e7bcde57454a431593"><span offset-key="ceb3eaceff2c47e7bcde57454a431593:0">Parameter context matching</span></span>

<span key="04414366de434f008c95dabd93184784"><span offset-key="04414366de434f008c95dabd93184784:0">We can use these same principles to bind arguments inside a function to properties of an object supplied as an argument:</span></span>

1

<span key="07ca29eda3384552bd5662a172cc8b56"><span offset-key="07ca29eda3384552bd5662a172cc8b56:0">const containsSpinach = ({ greens }) => {</span></span>

2

<span key="a1f113f294724b68bbf84fe12b6a7a6e"><span offset-key="a1f113f294724b68bbf84fe12b6a7a6e:0"> if (greens.find(g => g === 'spinach')) {</span></span>

3

<span key="293730bc43694b05881eb1b8ba25a073"><span offset-key="293730bc43694b05881eb1b8ba25a073:0"> return true;</span></span>

4

<span key="6923f5c798bc49fb8a3d2480df016ddc"><span offset-key="6923f5c798bc49fb8a3d2480df016ddc:0"> } else {</span></span>

5

<span key="cad6176fe7ce4f6ab64647b4cb1ea0f6"><span offset-key="cad6176fe7ce4f6ab64647b4cb1ea0f6:0"> return false;</span></span>

6

<span key="48049555ae2b4370930df27e9ec81c7a"><span offset-key="48049555ae2b4370930df27e9ec81c7a:0"> }</span></span>

7

<span key="58a6804f7a034f79ba77d5cf3a7aa78e"><span offset-key="58a6804f7a034f79ba77d5cf3a7aa78e:0">};</span></span>

8

<span key="5be8771a60c547febaddbf5ad0c58757"><span offset-key="5be8771a60c547febaddbf5ad0c58757:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

9

<span key="ae19c8f4630a4c8e8f57a7ee728f3d82"><span offset-key="ae19c8f4630a4c8e8f57a7ee728f3d82:0">containsSpinach(smoothie);</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ab16dcf7982149528cef4400bb9c9921"><span offset-key="ab16dcf7982149528cef4400bb9c9921:0">We do this often with functional React components:</span></span>

1

<span key="ebac9a54080a445dace43e7270d060b8"><span offset-key="ebac9a54080a445dace43e7270d060b8:0">const IngredientList = ({ ingredients, onClick }) => (</span></span>

2

<span key="d8da4f9bb6174d0e8bd672be908b184d"><span offset-key="d8da4f9bb6174d0e8bd672be908b184d:0"> &lt;ul className='IngredientList'></span></span>

3

<span key="d3acc746e38e4eab9f74a7b883492a5c"><span offset-key="d3acc746e38e4eab9f74a7b883492a5c:0"> {</span></span>

4

<span key="b00e7d4b5a404a9e95ffc969831aa2df"><span offset-key="b00e7d4b5a404a9e95ffc969831aa2df:0"> ingredients.map(i => (</span></span>

5

<span key="27490885ee1b43ac952d89ce41b37a89"><span offset-key="27490885ee1b43ac952d89ce41b37a89:0"> &lt;li</span></span>

6

<span key="05bd7831c3a0471e88020f789510cc4e"><span offset-key="05bd7831c3a0471e88020f789510cc4e:0"> key={i.id}</span></span>

7

<span key="dff9e1ef395d43dfab225e9248bff371"><span offset-key="dff9e1ef395d43dfab225e9248bff371:0"> onClick={() => onClick(i.id)}</span></span>

8

<span key="6617afde05254c1285c2bb8dc7f9d6d1"><span offset-key="6617afde05254c1285c2bb8dc7f9d6d1:0"> className='item'</span></span>

9

<span key="4491cd2a2dc64b3a80138bea71eeea57"><span offset-key="4491cd2a2dc64b3a80138bea71eeea57:0"> &gt;</span></span>

10

<span key="ef5ff7312a3b462995c1f8681833b44d"><span offset-key="ef5ff7312a3b462995c1f8681833b44d:0"> {i.name}</span></span>

11

<span key="d9fc32e40abd4b65972f92945036979a"><span offset-key="d9fc32e40abd4b65972f92945036979a:0"> &lt;/li></span></span>

12

<span key="ff779e5879224690a4d9fee6c1363885"><span offset-key="ff779e5879224690a4d9fee6c1363885:0"> ))</span></span>

13

<span key="6cf801c129a5448faa1e91ed70caade2"><span offset-key="6cf801c129a5448faa1e91ed70caade2:0"> }</span></span>

14

<span key="ea8bb226c0874cb0b5f7c64d95aa2ce8"><span offset-key="ea8bb226c0874cb0b5f7c64d95aa2ce8:0"> &lt;/ul></span></span>

15

<span key="3f0c19435e87495188d856b8ded1e30f"><span offset-key="3f0c19435e87495188d856b8ded1e30f:0">)</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="f61a0c99fd434746a7c238ab335bef59"><span offset-key="f61a0c99fd434746a7c238ab335bef59:0">Here, we use destructuring to extract the props into variables (</span>`ingredients`<span offset-key="f61a0c99fd434746a7c238ab335bef59:2"> and </span>`onClick`<span offset-key="f61a0c99fd434746a7c238ab335bef59:4">) that we then use inside the component's function body.</span></span>
